reviewText:
TL;DR Traditional comedy/horror point & click, with a great sense of humour and decent puzzles. If you don't mind a bit of cartoonish gore and some crude jokes in your adventure games, it should provide you around 3 hours of solid fun.

Metal Dead first came out at 2011, as the very low budget brain child of the two aussie developers behind Walk Thru Walls Studios. Despite its very basic art style, the low-fi music, the lack of voice acting, the short playtime and some minor (non game-breaking) bugs here and there, it completely embraces its crazy humour and oddball set of characters and ends up managing to both charm and entertain.

Immediately after your unlikely duo of metalhead heroes manage to crash their car right in front of what appears to be Zombie Central, everything turns from weird to weirder; including your protagonist Malcolm ending up with one of the funniest hint delivery systems in gaming history stuffed right into his pocket. (Feel free to use it now and then even if you aren't stuck, it offers some very amusing moments). Any more story details will, I feel, take away from your enjoyment, but suffice to say that the writing is quite polished. The dialogues are successful in delivering both jokes and a sense of character, and the insane plot ends up holding your interest despite (or because of) its absurdity. There are some unexpected twists and turns to enjoy, plus an oddball cast of engaging folks to save - or escort to their inevitable comedic demise. And while much of the humour could qualify as crude or gross, it somehow still manages to hit the mark more often than not.  As for the puzzles, they are all inventory based and mostly logical. I was happy to see that they tended to be backed up by dialogue and built neatly into the story instead of distracting from it. The difficulty isn't very high, but some of them are clever nonetheless.

There is something to be said about developers that succeed in making something this fun out of such a low budget, but you should still come to this game understanding that corners were (mostly gracefully) cut. The low-fi metal music has some nice moments, but I was more impressed with the clever use of sound effects that help emphasise the right points in the plot, either for shock value or for comedic effects. Similarly, the cartoonish art style may have character but is nonetheless very basic and doesn't scale well in larger monitors. However the animation saves it and deserves praise for its fluidity.

So Metal Dead is a fun little game, provided it finds the right audience that will appreciate its wacky sense of humor. I enjoyed replaying it, and I'm looking forward to Metal Dead: Encore[www.walkthruwalls.com], which is expected to stomp into our lives sometime in the next year or so.

This game shows thet simple can be good.  I doubt it will win any awards but you can expect maybe 6 hours of light hearted entertainment from an old school point and click.

Don't be put off by the simple art style or the lack of voicing. The best bits of the game come from the conversation between the eccentric characters and well designed (almost exclusively) logical puzzles. There were enough good one-liners to keep me chuckling all the way through. Some people may be put off by the amount of toilet humour but I wasn't.

Two negative points:
Sections of the game had some annoyingly repetetive music.
The interface used 4 interaction types: look, use, walk and talk. Just like most point and clicks  did back in the 90s. I actually wish more games had this but the designers of this game got a bit fussy over how big the hotspots were so you might find yourself stuck for a while even when you've been trying to do the right thing.
There are a bunch of references you won't get if you didn't play such things as 'Leisure Suit Larry'.  I didn't play it so there were a lot of moments where I was a bit confused.

I definitely recommend this to point and click fans

Metal Dead is a short adventure game set in a zombie apocalypse. The artwork was clearly done in MS Paint. There's no voice acting. It's not a game for everyone.

reviewText:
You are Malcolm, a typically untypical metalhead. He loves beer, cones, blast beats and his best friend Ronnie (Beavis + Butthead + a beard), but he is into death metal more than death period. With the undead apocalypse well underway, we find him sitting in Ronnie's car as they drive into the night - my bad, the Eternal Foreboding Grimdark - until an unfortunate accident strands them at the foot of a building towards which all the zombies seem to be converging, and threatens to separate them for good. Fear not! Science will help them reunite, and they will forge the kind of bond you can only experience with someone when you have spent a lot of time near their soiled underwear.
Just don't call Ronnie a punk lest he bites you where it counts.

I was surprised to find a very traditional point'n'click experience in Metal Dead. I'm not sure what I expected from a cursory glance; some kind of retro indie shooter/platformer? This is straightforward, old-school adventurin'. My playtime reaches almost 6 hours and that barely includes any time for backtracking and aimless wandering, because I'm that good - and mostly because the puzzles are deceptively well-designed and the flow is logical all the way to the end, even when the environment opens up.
In a way I'm sorry I didn't have to resort to the hint system, which is highly original and fun in its implementation.
It wasn't 6 solid hours of play though, as I'm so metal that I went to cook dinner IN THE MIDDLE OF A DAMN ZOMBIE INVASION. A meat dinner, of course! I'm not a hippie! (although we should all become vegan unless we want to be turned into zombies someday)

Metal Dead is a solid game, with no padding or inventory overload - I believe the only item I had left at the end was a badass red guitar. I see another reviewer say he completed it in 90 minutes and is now going for a speedrun; which seems very feasible but I'm sorry to say it's playing this wrong, like run'n'gunning your way through Dishonored. You're here for the script: the narrative is pleasantly goofy and over-the-top (should I say brutal?) and almost every item interaction is dignified with its own silly line.

If like me you find the ending sad, get to the Walk Thru Walls Studio website and quench your manly tears while you watch the trailer for sequel Metal Dead: Encore!

tl;dr - if you're a metalhead, Metal Dead was made for you. If you're not - what are you then, a punk? What are you doing in this mosh pit? Go listen to Gouge's song I Smell of Rotten Death[hellsheadbangers.bandcamp.com]. That is all.

Ah Metal Dead, what a fun little time waster with a good ending to lead up to a sequel.

reviewText:
Metal Dead is a fun, humours, point and click adventure game. It can get boring after a little especially if you don't know what to do, the resolution is small, and cannot be changed. It lags/stutters randomly... repetitive music to the point of extreme annoyance... but other than that, it is pretty good. I enjoyed the dialogue, although sometimes it went by too fast. Plot twists, references, gore, a severed head!
Some people have negative feelings with 'no voice acting', but I don't; lets me read the characters the way I want them to be. I just wish the text stayed on screen for a fraction longer.
The art style is Good. It reminded me of the flash games I'd play at school during lunch. It's not bad, just seemed lacking in something.
Animations were meh, but good enough I suppose.
Navigation:  You are given 4(+1) options for interacting: Look, Use/take/etc, Talk, Walk (and using items from inventory on objects in the room-- Standard in P&C). You have to right click to cycle through each one and it can be rather annoying; often over-click and select the wrong one. Get used to it eventually, but still get the odd extra click so I have to cycle through them again just to talk to someone. **I'm not a huge fan of Point & Clicks.
Sound: Music sounds like something you'd get from DOOM. Pretty good soundtrack, but extremely repetitive. Sound effects are decent.
Story: Plot-twists for your plot-twists.
Other notes: Random lag/stutters can be annoying. Manual save system, so save often.
* Only takes about 2-2.5 hours to beat. Maybe less if you follow a guide/know what you're doing.
Easy 100% achievements if you're into that.. (a few hidden ones that can be locked if you advance in the game too quickly - check a guide)

Highly recommend this game.  Played twice, Enjoyed twice.

reviewText:
Short version: 75%There is some overabundance of gore and disgusting scenes, but Metal Dead is a solid voiceless indie point ‘n’ click title that thankfully doesn’t take itself even the least bit serious.

Long version:If you are the kind of person who likes horror comedies which are full of guts and blood (and faecal matter), but don’t take themselves seriously, then you will like Metal Dead.

As a low-budget game it doesn’t have any voice acting, and the animation is quite crude. It focuses on the story instead, which is a standard zombie survival scenario, where you and a bunch of other people are trapped in a building (this time a hospital) and try to escape before the undead overrun you.
Many indie adventure games tend to have problems with puzzles that are either way too obvious or just insanely overcomplicated. Although Metal Dead has parts which need some luck or trial and error (which is a little awkward thanks to the not too user friendly interface), it’s almost impossible to get hopelessly stuck.

In essence, it may be like a Flash game with a price tag attached to it, but it’s enjoyable and fairly long for that price.

reviewText:
I wish this rating system was more complex. Personally, I liked the game, but I would only recommend it for die-hard graphic adventure fans who are also partial to horror comedy. (In this case, I totally fit the target demographic.)

The Good: Fun, engaging zombie comedy plot -- it plays like the b@stard child of Shaun of the Dead and Maniac Mansion. The story wisely puts characters ahead of gimmicks -- it does not require familiarity with *specific* aspects of zombie lore or heavy metal culture to enjoy. The big reveal in the end made the gameplay feel worth it.

The Bad: The gameplay is almost never time-sensitive and doesn't quite capture the dread and tension of an ongoing zombie apocalypse. The puzzles lack challenge for veteran adventure gamers. Minimal replay value once you've finished it.

The Ugly: The stylized character design -- heavily influenced by Jhonen Vasquez (Invader Zim, Johnny the Homicidal Maniac) -- is a niche taste. I was fine with it but I can see why others might not be.

reviewText:
A nice little indie adventure made with Adventure Game Studio, which is a pretty old and creaky engine by today's standards, but also has a proven track record of being able to perform miracles (like Time Gentlemen, Please!) in capable hands. Succeeding with AGS demands a lot from the writing department, and this is where Metal Dead shines.

The story follows the exploits of two metalheads in the middle of an zombie outbreak, and is just about as anarchistic that can be imagined from the premise. The game does not skimp on the gore, but it's all presented with a deftly light and funny touch and endearingly crude graphics. In fact, the game's sense of humor is its strongest asset: The dialogue and writing is generally quite funny and pokes a lot of fun at various pop and alternative culture phenomenons.

The puzzles are surprisingly logical as well, which does mean the game is a bit on the easy side. I don't really see that as a negative thing, however - It keeps the narrative moving and the jokes incoming, and Metal Dead is above all entertaining throughout its duration. It's not quite as laugh-out-loud funny as the Ben & Dan games, but worth experiencing nevertheless. Rough on the outside, but beats a lot of the generic adventure bulk put out by actual publishers with ease.
